name: Hideki Saijō
description:
{{Nihongo|'''Hideki Saijō'''|西城 秀樹|Saijō Hideki|originally {{nihongo|Tatsuo Kimoto|木本 龍雄|Kimoto Tatsuo}}; April 13, 1955 – May 16, 2018}} was a Japanese singer, composer, actor, drummer, voice actor, and television and radio show host. Due to his numerous pioneering achievements throughout Asia in the 1970s and 1980s, he is considered an icon amongst [[Shōwa era]] idols.

With on-stage vivacity and highly acclaimed vocals as his defining trademarks, Saijō quickly came to dominate the Japanese charts of the 1970s. He was consistently promoted as part of the {{nihongo3|"New Big Three"|新御三家|Shin-Gosanke}} idol trio alongside two other soloists who debuted around the same time: [[Goro Noguchi]] and [[Hiromi Go]]. Almost seven years into his career, his 28th single "YOUNG MAN (Y.M.C.A.)" (a Japanese cover of [[Y.M.C.A. (song)|the Village People song of the same name]]) became a social phenomenon in Japan, selling over 1.8 million copies.
